article.paragraph: Thedomestic catMSW3 Carnivora14000031534–535Species ''Felis catus''cite webhttp://www.itis.gov/servlet/SingleRpt/SingleRpt?search_topicITIS Standard Report Page: Felis catus ITIS Online Database 2011 [[Integrated Taxonomic Information System]] Reston, Virginia 14 December 2011(Felis catusorFelis silvestris catus)is a small, usuallyfurry,Domesticationdomesticated, andcarnivorecarnivorousmammal. They are often calledhousecatswhen kept as indoor pets or simplycatswhen there is no need to distinguish them from otherFelidaefelidsandFelinaefelines.cite bookhttp://education.yahoo.com/reference/dictionary/entry/housecat Housecat American Heritage Dictionary of the English Language Education.Yahoo.com online Houghton Mifflin Boston 2010 6 October 2010 Cats are often valued by humans for companionship and their ability to huntvermin.

Cats are similar inCat anatomyanatomyto the other felids, with strong, flexible bodies, quick reflexes, sharp retractable claws, and teeth adapted to killing small prey.Cat sensesfit acrepuscularand predatoryecological niche. Cats can hear sounds too faint or too high infrequencyfor human ears, such as those made by mice and other small animals. They can see in near darkness. Like most other mammals, cats have poorercolor visionand a betterOlfactionsense of smellthan humans.

Despite being solitary hunters, cats are asocial animalsocial speciesandcat communicationincludes the use of a variety ofAnimal communicationvocalizations(Cat communicationmewing,purring,Trill consonanttrilling, hissing,growling, andGutturalgrunting), as well ascat pheromonesand types ofCat body languagecat-specific body language.

Cats have a high breeding rate. Under controlled breeding, they can be bred and shown asCat registryregisteredpedigree pets, a hobby known ascat fancy. Failure to control the breeding of pet cats byneuteringand theAbandoned petsabandonment of former household petshas resulted in large numbers offeral catsworldwide, requiringanimal population controlpopulation control.Cite bookRochlitzIreneThe Welfare of Cats"Animal Welfare" series2007SpringerBerlin141–1751-4020-6143-9This has contributed, along with habitat destruction and other factors, to extinction of many bird species. Cats have been known to extirpate a bird species within a specific region and may have contributed to extinction of isolated island populations.Impact of Feral Cats in AustraliaCats are thought to be primarily, though not solely, responsible for the extinction of 33 species of birds, and the presence of feral and free ranging cats makes some locations unsuitable for attempted species reestablishment in otherwise suitable locations.Winters, L, Walter GEIMPACTS of FERAL and FREE-RANGING CATS on Bird Species of Conservation ConcernAmerican Bird Conservancy, 31 May 2005.

Since cats wereCats in ancient Egyptvenerated in ancient Egypt, they were commonly believed to have been domesticated there,Cite newshttp://www.nytimes.com/2007/06/29/science/29cat.html Study Traces Cat's Ancestry to Middle East Wade Nicholas 29 June 2007 New York Times [[New York Times Company|NYTC]] New York 2 April 2008but there may have been instances of domestication as early as theNeolithicfrom around 9,500 years ago (7,500 BC).cite journalVigne JD, Guilaine J, Debue K, Haye L, Gérard PEarly taming of the cat in CyprusScience3045668259April 20041507337010.1126/science.1095335A genetic study in 2007 concluded that domestic cats are descended fromAfrican wildcats(Felis silvestris lybica), having diverged around 8,000 BC inWest Asia.cite webOldest Known Pet Cat? 9,500-year-old Burial Found on Cyprus http://news.nationalgeographic.com/news/2004/04/0408_040408_oldestpetcat.html 6 March 2007 8 April 2004 National Geographic News National Geographic Society Cats are the most popular pet in the world, and are now found in almost every place where humans live.cite webhttp://www.scientificamerican.com/article.cfm?idThe Evolution of House Cats Scientific American Carlos A. Driscoll Clutton-Brock, JulietKitchener, Andrew C.O'Brien, Stephen J. Nature Pubg. Group New York 10 June 2009 26 August 2009

There are more than 70 cat breeds around the world. Different associations proclaim different numbers according to their standards. The International Progressive Cat Breeders Alliance (IPCBA) recognizes 73 cat breeds while TICA (The International Cat Association) recognizes 58, CFA (The Cat Fanciers' Association) recognizes 44 and Federation International Feline (FIFE) recognizes 43 cat breeds.Cite webPopular Cat Breedshttp://www.different-cat-breeds.com/popular-cat-breeds.html14 September 2015
article.heading: History and mythology
article.paragraph: MainCultural depictions of catsCats in ancient EgyptFile:PSM V37 D105 English tabby cat.jpgthumbrightA 19th century drawing of a tabby catTraditionally, historians tended to thinkancient Egyptwas the site of cat domestication, owing to the clear depictions of house cats in Egyptian paintings about 3,600 years old.However, in 2004, a Neolithic grave excavated inShillourokambos, Cyprus, contained the skeletons, laid close to one another, of both a human and a cat. The grave is estimated to be 9,500 years old, pushing back the earliest known felinehuman association significantly.Cite newsAncient Remains Could Be Oldest Pet Cat Muir Hazel [[New Scientist]] 8 April 2004 http://www.newscientist.com/article/dn4867.html 23 November 2007 Cite newsAncient Burial Looks Like Human and Pet Cat Walton Marsha CNN 9 April 2004 http://edition.cnn.com/2004/TECH/science/04/08/cats.cyprus/index.html 23 November 2007 The cat specimen is large and closely resembles the African wildcat (F. s. lybica), rather than present-day domestic cats. This discovery, combined with genetic studies, suggests cats were probably domesticated in the Middle East, in theFertile Crescentaround the time of theHistory of agriculturedevelopment of agricultureand then they were brought to Cyprus and Egypt.Cite journalDriscoll CA, Menotti-Raymond M, Roca ALThe Near Eastern origin of cat domesticationScience3175837519–2320071760018510.1126/science.11395182007Sci...317..519D

Direct evidence for the domestication of cats 5,300 years ago in Quanhucun in China has been published. The cats are believed to have been attracted to the village by rodents, which in turn were attracted by grain cultivated and stored by humans.cite webhttp://www.nacion.com/vivir/ciencia/Gatos-domesticados-China-hace-anos_0_1385061482.htmlGatos fueron domesticados en China hace 5.300 añosLa Nación9 September 2014

In ancient Egypt, cats wereanimal worshipsacred animals, with the goddessBastetoften depicted in cat form, sometimes taking on the war-like aspect of a lioness.Cite bookMasonI. L.Evolution of Domesticated Animals1984Prentice Hall Press0-582-46046-8rp220TheAncient RomeRomansare often credited with introducing the domestic cat from Egypt to Europe;rp223inGallia AquitaniaRoman Aquitaine, a first- or second-centuryengravingof a young girl holding a cat is one of two earliest depictions of the Roman domesticated cat.cite bookVeynePaul[[Arthur Goldhammer]] (Trans.)The Roman EmpireHarvard CollegeCambridge, Massachusetts200219873rd81The Household and Its Freed Slaves0-674-77771-9https://books.google.com/?idHowever, cats possibly were already kept in Europe prior to theRoman Empire, as they may have been present in Britain in the lateIron Age.Domestic cats were spread throughout much of the rest of the world during theAge of Discovery, as they were carried onsailing shipsto control shipboard rodents and as good-luck charms.rp223

Several ancient religions believed cats are exalted souls, companions or guides for humans, that are all-knowing but mute so they cannot influence decisions made by humans. In Japan, themaneki nekocat is a symbol of good fortune.

Although no species are sacred in Islam,cats and Islamcats are revered by Muslims. Some Western writers have statedMuhammadhad a favorite cat,Muezza.Cite bookGeyerGeorgie AnneWhen Cats Reigned Like Kings: On the Trail of the Sacred CatsAndrews McMeelKansas City, Missouri20040-7407-4697-9He is reported to have loved cats so much, "he would do without his cloak rather than disturb one that was sleeping on it".Cite bookMinou ReevesMuhammad in EuropeNew York University (NYU) Press520-8147-7533-02000The story has no origin in early Muslim writers, and seems to confuse a story of a laterSufisaint,Ahmed ar-Rifa'icenturies after Muhammad.Cite webhttp://library.islamweb.net/newlibrary/display_book.php?idfromBiography of al-Rifai Al-Thahabi Shamsuddin [[سير أعلام النبلاء]] 11 November 2014
Freyja, the goddess of love, beauty, and fertility inNorse mythology, is depicted as riding a chariot drawn by cats.

Many cultures have negativesuperstitionsabout cats. An example would be the belief that ablack cat"crossing one's path" leads to bad luck, or that cats are witches'familiar spiritfamiliarsused to augment a witch's powers and skills. The killing of cats in MedievalYpres,Belgium, is commemorated in the innocuous present-dayKattenstoet(cat parade).citation neededApril 2013

According to a myth in many cultures, cats have multiple lives. In many countries, they are believed to have nine lives, but in Italy, Germany, Greece, and some Spanish-speaking regions, they are said to have seven lives,Cite newshttp://elcomercio.pe/impresa/notas/vidas-gato/20100307/4239597 March 201019 March 2010Nora SugobonoSpanishLas vidas del gatoEl Comerciowhile in Turkish and Arabic traditions, the number of lives is six.Cite newsThe GuardianUKhttp://www.guardian.co.uk/lifeandstyle/gallery/2010/mar/18/guide-to-pets-pet-myths?picture18 March 2010Tim DowlingTall tails: Pet myths busted19 March 2010The myth is attributed to the natural suppleness and swiftness cats exhibit to escape life-threatening situations.cite webhttp://www.best-cat-art.com/cat-myths.htmlCat Myths, Misinformation and UntruthsRosinaWachtmeisterBest-Cat-Art.com2008self-published22 November 2008self-published sourceDecember 2011Also lending credence to this myth is the fact that falling cats often land on their feet, using an instinctivecat righting reflexrighting reflexto twist their bodies around. Nonetheless, cats can still be injured or killed by a high fall.cite webhttp://cats.about.com/od/catsafety/a/highrisefalls.htmThe ASPCA Warns About High-Rise Falls by CatsASPCA30 June 2005About.com26 April 2012New York

APedigree (cat)pedigreed catis one whose ancestry is recorded by aCat fancycat fancierorganization. Apurebred catis one whose ancestry contains only individuals of the same breed. Many pedigreed and especially purebred cats are exhibited asshow cats. Cats of unrecorded, mixed ancestry are referred to asDomestic short-haired catdomestic short-hairedordomestic long-haired cats, byCoat (animal)coattype, or commonly as random-bred, moggies (chieflyBritish EnglishBritish), or (using terms borrowed fromDog breedsdog breeding) mongrels or mutt-cats.

While theAfrican wildcatis the ancestral subspecies from which domestic cats are descended, and wildcats and domestic cats can completely interbreed, several intermediate stages occur between domestic pet and pedigree cats on one hand and those entirely wild animals on the other. The semiferal cat, a mostly outdoor cat, is not owned by any one individual, but is generally friendly to people and may be fed by several households.Feral catsare associated with human habitation areas and may be fed by people or forage in rubbish, but are typically wary of human interaction.

Cats have sevencervical vertebrae, as do almost allmammals; 13thoracic vertebrae(humans have 12); sevenlumbar vertebrae(humans have five); threesacrumsacral vertebraelike most mammals (humans have five); and a variable number ofcaudal vertebraein the tail (humans retain three to five caudal vertebrae, fused into an internalcoccyx).Cite bookStudy of the Cat with Reference to Human Beings Walker Warren F. 4th Revised 1982 Thomson Learning 0-03-057914-7 rp11The extra lumbar and thoracic vertebrae account for the cat's spinal mobility and flexibility. Attached to the spine are 13 ribs, the shoulder, and thepelvis.rp16Unlike human arms, cat forelimbs are attached to the shoulder by free-floatingclaviclebones which allow them to pass their bodies through any space into which they can fit their heads.cite webCat Skeleton Gillis Rick (ed.) Zoolab: A Website for Animal Biology University of Wisconsin La Crosse, WI 22 July 2002 http://bioweb.uwlax.edu/zoolab/Table_of_Contents/Lab-9b/Cat_Skeleton_1/cat_skeleton_1.htm https://web.archive.org/web/20061206105542/http://bioweb.uwlax.edu/zoolab/Table_of_Contents/Lab-9b/Cat_Skeleton_1/cat_skeleton_1.htm 6 December 2006 7 September 2012

File:Cat skull.jpgthumbrightCat skullThe cat skull is unusual among mammals in having very largeeye socketsand a powerful and specialized jaw.Cite bookThe Cat: Its Behavior, Nutrition, and Health Case Linda P. 2003 Iowa State University Press Ames, IA 0-8138-0331-4 rp35Within the jaw, cats have teeth adapted for killing prey and tearing meat. When it overpowers its prey, a cat delivers a lethal neck bite with its two longCanine toothcanine teeth, inserting them between two of the prey's vertebrae and severing itsspinal cord, causing irreversibleparalysisand death.Cite bookStructure, Function and Evolution of teeth Smith Patricia Tchernov Eitan 1992 217 Freund Publishing House Ltd. 965-222-270-4 Compared to other felines, domestic cats have narrowly spaced canine teeth, which is an adaptation to their preferred prey of small rodents, which have small vertebrae.Thepremolarand firstMolar (tooth)molartogether compose thecarnassialpair on each side of the mouth, which efficiently shears meat into small pieces, like a pair ofscissors. These are vital in feeding, since cats' smallmolar (tooth)molarscannot chew food effectively.rp37

Cats, like dogs, aredigitigrades. They walk directly on their toes, with the bones of their feet making up the lower part of the visible leg.Cite journalMotor Patterns in Walking Lacquaniti F. Grasso R. Zago M. News Physiol. Sci. 14 4 168–174 1 August 1999 11390844 Cats are capable of walking very precisely, because like allFelinaefelines, they directly register; that is, they place each hind paw (almost) directly in the print of the corresponding fore paw, minimizing noise and visible tracks. This also provides sure footing for their hind paws when they navigate rough terrain. Unlike most mammals, when cats walk, they use a "pacing"gait; that is, they move the two legs on one side of the body before the legs on the other side. This trait is shared withcamelsandgiraffes. As a walk speeds up into a trot, a cat's gait changes to be a "diagonal" gait, similar to that of most other mammals (and many other land animals, such aslizards): the diagonally opposite hind and fore legs move simultaneously.Cite bookOutwitting Cats Christensen Wendy 23 Globe Pequot 2004 1-59228-240-7 https://books.google.com/?id

Like almost all members of the Felidae, cats have protractable and retractableclaws.Cite journalClaw Retraction and Protraction in the Carnivora: The Cheetah (Acinonyx Jubatus) as an Atypical Felid Russell Anthony P. Bryant Harold N. Journal of Zoology 2001 254 1 67–76 10.1017/S0952836901000565 In their normal, relaxed position, the claws are sheathed with the skin andfuraround thepaw's toe pads. This keeps the claws sharp by preventing wear from contact with the ground and allows the silent stalking of prey. The claws on the fore feet are typically sharper than those on the hind feet.Cite journalOutline of Cat Lessons Armes Annetta F. The School Journal 22 December 1900 LXI 659 E. L. Kellogg & Co https://books.google.com/?id12 November 2007 Cats can voluntarily extend their claws on one or more paws. They may extend their claws in hunting or self-defense, climbing,kneading (cats)kneading, or for extra traction on soft surfaces. Most cats have five claws on their front paws, and four on their rear paws.cite journalDanforth CHHeredity of polydactyly in the catThe Journal of Heredity384107–12April 194720242531http://jhered.oxfordjournals.org/content/38/4/107.full.pdfThe fifth front claw (thedewclaw) isproximalto the other claws. More proximally is a protrusion which appears to be a sixth "finger". This special feature of the front paws, on the inside of the wrists, is the carpal pad, also found on the paws ofbig catsand of dogs. It has no function in normal walking, but is thought to be an antiskidding device used while jumping. Some breeds of cats are prone toPolydactyl catpolydactyly(extra toes and claws).These are particularly common along the northeast coast of North America.cite journalLettice LA, Hill AE, Devenney PS, Hill REPoint mutations in a distant sonic hedgehog cis-regulator generate a variable regulatory output responsible for preaxial polydactylyHuman Molecular Genetics177978–85April 20081815615710.1093/hmg/ddm370

article.paragraph: File:Termografia kot.jpgthumbThermographCats are familiar and easily kept animals, and their physiology has been particularly well studied; it generally resembles those of other carnivorous mammals, but displays several unusual features probably attributable to cats' descent from desert-dwelling species.For instance, cats are able to tolerate quite high temperatures: Humans generally start to feel uncomfortable when their skin temperature passes about 38 C (100 F), but cats show no discomfort until their skin reaches around 52 C (126 F),rp46and can tolerate temperatures of up to 56 C (133 F) if they have access to water.Cite bookSubcommittee on Dog and Cat Nutrition Nutrient Requirements of Dogs and Cats National Academies Press Washington, DC 2006 292 0-309-08628-0

Cats conserve heat by reducing the flow of blood to their skin and lose heat by evaporation through their mouths. Cats have minimal ability to sweat, with glands located primarily in their paw pads,cite webhttp://www.cathealth.com/how-and-why/how-do-cats-sweatHow do cats sweat?Cat Health,com24 February 2014andThermoregulationpant for heat reliefonly at very high temperaturesCite journalTemperature Regulation of the Unanesthetized Cat During Mild Cold and Severe Heat Stress Adams T. Morgan, M. L.Hunter, W. S.Holmes, K. R. Journal of Applied Physiology 29 6 852–858 1970 5485356 (but may also pant when stressed). A cat's body temperature does not vary throughout the day; this is part of cats' general lack ofcircadian rhythmsand may reflect their tendency to be active both during the day and at night.Cite bookCommittee on Animal Nutrition Nutrient Requirements of Cats 1986 2nd National Academy Pr http://www.nap.edu/catalog.php?record_idrp1Cats' feces are comparatively dry and their urine is highly concentrated, both of which are adaptations to allow cats to retain as much water as possible.Their kidneys are so efficient, they can survive on a diet consisting only of meat, with no additional water,Cite journalHydropenia in Cat and Dog: Ability of the Cat to Meet its Water Requirements Solely from a Diet of Fish or Meat Prentiss Phoebe G. American Journal of Physiology 196 3 625–632 1959 13627237 and can even rehydrate by drinkingseawater.rp29Cite journalPotability of Sea Water with Special Reference to the Cat Wolf A. V. American Journal of Physiology 1959 196 3 633–641 13627238

Cats areobligate carnivores: theirphysiologyhas evolved to efficiently process meat, and they have difficulty digesting plant matter.Cite journalNutrition of the domestic cat, a mammalian carnivore MacDonald M. L. Rogers Q. R. Morris J. G. Annual Review of Nutrition 4 521–562 1984 6380542 10.1146/annurev.nu.04.070184.002513 In contrast toomnivoressuch asrats, which only require about 4% protein in their diet, about 20% of a cat's diet must be protein.Cats are unusually dependent on a constant supply of theamino acidarginine, and a diet lacking arginine causes marked weight loss and can be rapidly fatal.Cite journalArginine: An Essential Amino Acid for the Cat Morris J. G. Rogers Q. R. Journal of Nutrition 108 12 1944–1953 1 December 1978 722344 Another unusual feature is that the cat cannot producetaurine, with taurine deficiency causingmacular degeneration, wherein the cat's retina slowly degenerates, causing irreversible blindness.Since cats tend to eat all of their prey, they obtain minerals by digesting animal bones, and a diet composed only of meat may causecalciumdeficiency.

A cat'sgastrointestinal tractis adapted to meat eating, being much shorter than that of omnivores and having low levels of several of thedigestive enzymesneeded to digest carbohydrates.Cite journalZoran D. L. The Carnivore Connection to Nutrition in Cats Journal of the American Veterinary Medical Association 221 11 1559–1567 2002 12479324 10.2460/javma.2002.221.1559 http://www.rawessentials.co.nz/media/documents/website%20-zorans_article.pdf dead linkJanuary 2013These traits severely limit the cat's ability to digest and use plant-derived nutrients, as well as certainfatty acids.Despite the cat's meat-oriented physiology, several vegetarian or vegan cat foods have been marketed that are supplemented withchemical synthesischemically synthesizedtaurine and other nutrients, in attempts to produce a complete diet. However, some of these products still fail to provide all the nutrients cats require,Cite journalGray C. M. Sellon R. K. Freeman L. M. Nutritional Adequacy of Two Vegan Diets for Cats Journal of the American Veterinary Medical Association 225 11 1670–1675 2004 15626215 10.2460/javma.2004.225.1670 and diets containing no animal products pose the risk of causing severe nutritional deficiencies.Cite journalNutritional Peculiarities and Diet Palatability in the Cat Zaghini G. Biagi G. Vet. Res. Commun. 29 Supplement 2 39–44 2005 16244923 10.1007/s11259-005-0009-1

Cats do eatgrassoccasionally. A proposed explanation is that cats use grass as a source offolic acid. Another proposed explanation is that it is used to supplydietary fiber.cite webhttp://animal.discovery.com/healthy-pets/cat-health-101/why-do-cats-eat-grass.htmlCat Health 101: Why Do Cats Eat Grass?AnimalPlanet.com16 November 201113 August 2012

Exp. Biol.209Pt 118–2520061635477410.1242/jeb.01959Indeed, at low light levels a cat's pupils will expand to cover most of the exposed surface of its eyes.Cite journalHammond P. Mouat G. S. V. The relationship between feline pupil size and luminance Experimental Brain Research 1985 59 3 485–490 10.1007/BF00261338 However, domestic cats have rather poorcolor visionand (like most nonprimate mammals) have only two types ofCone cellcones, optimized for sensitivity to blue and yellowish green; they have limited ability to distinguish between red and green.Cite journalCat Color Vision: The Effect of Stimulus Size Loop M. S. Bruce L. L. Science 199 4334 1221–1222 1978 628838 10.1126/science.628838O 1978Sci...199.1221L A 1993 paper reported a response to middle wavelengths from a system other than theRod cellrodswhich might be due to a third type of cone. However, this appears to be an adaptation to low light levels rather than representing trueTrichromacytrichromaticvision.Cite journalGuenther Elke Zrenner Eberhart The Spectral Sensitivity of Dark- and Light-adapted Cat Retinal Ganglion Cells Journal of Neuroscience 13 1543–1550 April 1993 http://www.jneurosci.org/content/13/4/1543.full.pdf+html 48463834

Cats have excellent hearing and can detect an extremely broad range of frequencies. They can hear higher-pitched sounds than either dogs or humans, detecting frequencies from 55 Hz to 79,000 Hz, a range of 10.5 octaves, while humans and dogs both have ranges of about 9 octaves.Cite journalPrimate hearing from a mammalian perspective Heffner Rickye S. The Anatomical Record. In the early 1980s it was about seven years,rp33rising to 9.4 years in 1995rp33and 1215 years in 2014.cite webhttp://cats.about.com/cs/catmanagement101/f/lifespan_cats.htmWhat Is the Life Span of the Common Cat?Franny SyufyAbout.com Home2 September 2015However, cats have been reported as surviving into their 30s,Example:cite webMe-wow! Texas Woman Says Cat is 30 Years Old – Although She Can't Hear or See Very Well, Caterack the Cat Is Still Purring 30 September 2009 MSNBC.MSN.com Microsoft New York https://web.archive.org/web/20091002231250/http://today.msnbc.msn.com/id/33094898/ns/today-today_pets_and_animals?GT12 October 2009 http://today.msnbc.msn.com/id/33094898/ns/today-today_pets_and_animals?GT130 September 2009 with the oldest known cat,Creme Puff (cat)Creme Puff, dying at a verified age of 38.cite bookGuinness World Records 2010 Bantam reprint 320 The oldest cat ever was Creme Puff, who [sic] was born on August 3, 1967 and lived until August 6, 2005 – 38 years and 3 days in total. https://books.google.com/?id978-0-553-59337-2

Spaying or neutering increases life expectancy: one study found neutered male cats live twice as long as intact males, while spayed female cats live 62% longer than intact females.rp35Non-neutered cats in the U.S. are four times as likely to be hit by a car as a neutered cat, and are three times more likely to require treatment for an animal bite.Having a catNeuteringneuteredconfers health benefits, because castrated males cannot developtesticular cancer, spayed females cannot developUterine canceruterineorovarian cancer, and both have a reduced risk ofMammary tumormammary cancer.cite webhttp://www.aspca.org/pet-care/cat-care/spay-neuter.html Cat Care: Spay–Neuter ASPCA.org [[American Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Animals]] New York 2011 14 December 2011tertiaryDecember 2011

Despite widespread concern about the welfare of free-roaming cats, the lifespans of neutered feral cats in managed colonies compare favourably with those of pet cats.rp45rp1358Neutered cats in managed colonies can also live long lives.
article.heading: Diseases
article.paragraph: Cats can suffer from a wide range of health problems, including infectious diseases, parasites, injuries, and chronic disease.Feline vaccinationVaccinationsare available for many of these diseases, and domestic cats are regularly given treatments to eliminate parasites such as worms and fleas.
article.heading: Poisoning
article.paragraph: In addition to obvious dangers such asrodenticides,insecticides, andherbicides, cats may be poisoned by many chemicals usually considered safe by their human guardians,because their livers are less effective at some forms ofdetoxificationthan those of many other animals, including humans and dogs.Cite journalWilliams R. T. Species Variations in the Pathways of Drug Metabolism Environmental Health Perspectives 22 133–138 1 February 1978 417918 1637137 10.2307/3428562 3428562 Some of the most common causes of poisoning in cats are antifreeze and rodent baits.Cite journalRowland J. Incidence of Ethylene Glycol Intoxication in Dogs and Cats Seen at Colorado State University Veterinary Teaching Hospital Vet Hum Toxicol 29 1 41–44 1987 3824875 Cats may be particularly sensitive to environmental pollutants.Cite journalPotera C. Chemical Exposures: Cats as Sentinel Species Environmental Health Perspectives 115 12 A580 2007 18087575 2137107 10.1289/ehp.115-a580a When a cat has a sudden or prolonged serious illness without any obvious cause, it has possibly been exposed to a toxin.

Many human medicines should never be given to cats. For example, the painkillerparacetamol(or acetaminophen, sold asTylenol (brand)TylenolandPanadol (brand)Panadol) is extremely toxic to cats: even very small doses need immediate treatment and can be fatal.Cite journalAllen A. L. The Diagnosis of Acetaminophen Toxicosis in a Cat Canadian Veterinary Journal 1 June 2003 509–510 44 6 12839249 340185 Cite journalVillar D. Buck W. B. Gonzalez J. M. Ibuprofen, Aspirin and Acetaminophen Toxicosis and Treatment in Dogs and Cats Vet. Hum. Toxicol. 1998 156–162 40 3 9610496 Evenaspirin, which is sometimes used to treatarthritisin cats, is much more toxic to them than to humansand must be administered cautiously.Similarly, application ofminoxidil(Rogaine) to the skin of cats, either accidentally or by well-meaning guardians attempting to counter loss of fur, has sometimes been fatal.Cite journalSuspected Toxicosis after Topical Administration of Minoxidil in Two Cats DeClementi Camille Bailey, Keith L.Goldstein, Spencer C.Orser, Michael Scott Journal of Veterinary Emergency and Critical Care 2004 287–292 14 4 10.1111/j.1476-4431.2004.04014.x Essential oilscan be toxic to cats and cases have been reported of serious illnesses caused bytea tree oil, including flea treatments and shampoos containing it.cite journalBischoff K, Guale FAustralian tea tree (Melaleuca alternifolia) oil poisoning in three purebred catsJournal of Veterinary Diagnostic Investigation102208–10April 1998957635810.1177/104063879801000223

Other common household substances that should be used with caution around cats includemothballsand othernaphthaleneproducts.cite webhttp://www.vetinfo.com/ctoxin.html Toxic to Cats VetInfo.com 2011 14 December 2011 tertiaryDecember 2011Phenol-based products (e.g.Pine-Sol,Dettol(Lysol) orhexachlorophene)are often used for cleaning and disinfecting near cats' feeding areas orlitter boxes, but these can sometimes be fatal.Cite journalRousseaux C. G. Smith R. A. Nicholson S. Methylxanthine Toxicosis Veterinary Technician 2001 25 August 2009 Large amounts of onions or garlic are also poisonous to cats.Manyhouseplantsare also dangerous,cite webPlants and Your Cat http://www.cfainc.org/articles/plants.html http://www.webcitation.org/5mq1hjPbF 17 January 2010 Cat Fanciers' Association 15 May 2007such asPhilodendronspecies and the leaves of the Easter lily (Lilium longiflorum), which can cause permanent and life-threatening kidney damage.Cite journalAcute Renal Failure Caused by Lily Ingestion in Six Cats Langston Cathy E. Journal of the American Veterinary Medical Association 1 January 2002 220 1 49–52, 36 12680447 10.2460/javma.2002.220.49
article.heading: Behavior
article.paragraph: See alsoCat behaviorCat intelligenceFree-ranging cats are active both day and night, although they tend to be slightly more active at night.Cite journalSpatio-temporal Sharing between the European Wildcat, the Domestic Cat and their Hybrids Germain E. Benhamou S. Poulle M.-L. Journal of Zoology 2008 276 2 195–203 10.1111/j.1469-7998.2008.00479.x Cite journalBarratt David G. F.Randall, S.Cunningham, J. T. Behavioral Neuroscience 1985 99 6 3843546 10.1037/0735-7044.99.6.1162 1162–1175 Although they spend the majority of their time in the vicinity of their home, housecats can range many hundreds of meters from this central point, and are known to establishTerritory (animal)territoriesthat vary considerably in size, in one study ranging fromconvert7to(-)28haacre.

Cats conserve energy by sleeping more than most animals, especially as they grow older. The daily duration of sleep varies, usually 1216 hours, with 1314 being the average. Some cats can sleep as much as 20 hours in a 24-hour period. The term "wikt:cat napcat nap" for a short rest refers to the cat's tendency to fall asleep (lightly) for a brief period. While asleep, cats experience short periods ofrapid eye movement sleepoften accompanied by muscle twitches, which suggests they aredreaming.Cite journal10.1016/0166-2236(79)90110-3 2 280–282 Jouvet Michel What Does a Cat Dream About? Trends in Neurosciences 1979
article.heading: Sociability
article.paragraph: File:Listen, do you want to know a secret.jpgthumbrightSocial groomingAlthough wildcats are solitary, the social behavior of domestic cats is much more variable and ranges from widely dispersed individuals toFeral cat colonyferal cat coloniesthat form around a food source, based on groups of co-operating females.Cite journal10.1016/0376-6357(95)00070-4 37 1 85–88 Pontier Dominique Eugenia Natoli Male Reproductive Success in the Domestic Cat (''Felis catus'' L.): A Case History Behavioural Processes 1996 Cite journalSocial Organization in the Cat: A Modern Understanding Crowell-Davis S. L. Curtis T. M. Knowles R. J. 2004 Journal of Feline Medicine and Surgery 6 1 19–28 http://zoopsy.free.fr/veille_biblio/social_organization_cat_2004.pdf 21 May 2008 10.1016/j.jfms.2003.09.01315123163 Within such groups, one cat is usually dominant over the others.Cite journalPatterns of Social Interaction in Cats (''Felis domestica'') Baron Alan Stewart C. N. Warren J. M. Behaviour 1 January 1957 10.1163/156853956X00084 11 1 56–66 4532869 Each cat in a colony holds a distinct territory, with sexually active males having the largest territories, which are about 10 times larger than those of female cats and may overlap with several females' territories.Cite journal10.1016/S0168-1591(98)00102-6 57 3–4 269–286 Sommerville B. A. Olfactory Awareness Applied Animal Behaviour Science 1998 These territories are marked byurine spraying, by rubbing objects at head height with secretions from facial glands, and by defecation.Between these territories are neutral areas where cats watch and greet one another without territorial conflicts. Outside these neutral areas, territory holders usually chase away stranger cats, at first by staring, hissing, andgrowling, and if that does not work, by short but noisy and violent attacks. Despite some cats cohabiting in colonies, they do not have a social survival strategy, or aHerd behaviorpack mentality, and always hunt alone.

article.paragraph: However, some pet cats are poorly socialized. In particular, older cats may show aggressiveness towards newly arrived kittens, which may include biting and scratching; this type of behavior is known as feline asocial aggression.Cite journalIntercat Aggression in Households Following the Introduction of a New Cat Levine E. Perry, P.Scarlett, J.Houpt, K. Applied Animal Behaviour Science 90 2005 325–336 10.1016/j.applanim.2004.07.006 90 8 April 2009 http://faculty.washington.edu/jcha/330_cats_introducing.pdf

Though cats and dogs areDogcat relationshipbelieved to be natural enemies, they can live together if correctly socialized.cite webhttp://www.petuniversity.com/dogs/training--behavior/dogs-and-cats.htmDogs and Cats – Getting AlongPetuniversity.com4 July 2013

Life in proximity to humans and other domestic animals has led to a symbiotic social adaptation in cats, and cats may express great affection toward humans or other animals.EthologyEthologically, the human keeper of a cat may function as a sort of surrogate for the cat's mother,citation neededSeptember 2012and adult housecats live their lives in a kind of extended kittenhood,cite webhttp://animal.discovery.com/guides/cats/body/maturity.html https://web.archive.org/web/20080630205100/http://animal.discovery.com/guides/cats/body/maturity.html 30 June 2008 The Cat Body: Adolescence and Sexual Maturity "Cat Guide" section 2007 AnimalPlanet.com (Animal.Discovery.com) Discovery Communications a form of behavioralneoteny. The high-pitched sounds housecats make to solicit food may mimic the cries of a hungry human infant, making them particularly hard for humans to ignore.Cite journalMcComb K. Taylor, A. M.Wilson, C.Charlton, B. D. The Cry Embedded within the Purr Curr. Biol. 19 13 R507–508 2009 19602409 10.1016/j.cub.2009.05.033
article.heading: Communication
article.paragraph: mainCat communicationDomestic cats use manyAnimal communicationvocalizationsfor communication, includingpurring,Trill consonanttrilling, hissing,growling/snarling,Gutturalgrunting, and several different forms ofmeowing.Cite journalVocalizing in the House-cat; A Phonetic and Functional Study Moelk Mildred The American Journal of Psychology April 1944 57 2 184–205 10.2307/1416947 1416947 By contrast, feral cats are generally silent.Cite bookJensen Per The Ethology of Domestic Animals "Modular Text" series CABI Wallingford, England 2009 1-84593-536-5 rp208Their types ofCat body languagebody language, including position of ears and tail, relaxation of whole body, and kneading of paws, are all indicators of mood. The tail and ears are particularly important social signal mechanisms in cats,Cite journalCafazzo S. Natoli E. The Social Function of Tail Up in the Domestic Cat (''Felis silvestris catus'') Behav. Processes 80 1 60–66 2009 18930121 10.1016/j.beproc.2008.09.008 e.g. with a raised tail acting as a friendly greeting, and flattened ears indicating hostility. Tail-raising also indicates the cat's position in the group'ssocial hierarchy, with dominant individuals raising their tails less often than subordinate animals.Nose-to-nose touching is also a common greeting and may be followed bysocial grooming, which is solicited by one of the cats raising and tilting its head.

Purring may have developed as an evolutionary advantage as a signalling mechanism of reassurance between mother cats andBreastfeedingnursingkittens. Post-nursing cats often purr as a sign of contentment: when being petted, becoming relaxed,cite webhttp://www.bksv.com/catspurrSolving The Cat's Purr Mystery using AccelerometersBrüel & Kjær Magazine11 February 2010cite webhttp://www.isnare.com/?aidThe Cat's Remarkable Purrisnare.com6 August 2008or eating. The mechanism by which cats purr is elusive. The cat has no unique anatomical feature that is clearly responsible for the sound.cite webhttp://www.loc.gov/rr/scitech/mysteries/catspurr.htmlWhy and How Do Cats Purr?Library of Congress10 April 2011It was, until recent times, believed that only the cats of theFelisgenuscould purr. However, felids of thePantheragenus (tiger,lion,jaguar, andleopard) also produce sounds similar to purring, but only when exhaling.cite webhttp://www.panthera.org/Panthera23 November 2013
article.heading: Grooming

link.part: The hooked papillae on a cat's tongue act like ahairbrushto help clean and detangle fur.

article.paragraph: Cats are known for spending considerable amounts of time licking their coat to keep it clean.The cat'stonguehas backwards-facing spines about 500 micrometremlong, which are calledFiliform papillapapillae. These containkeratinwhich makes them quite rigidCite journalFiliform Papillae of Cat Tongue Boshel J. Wilborn, W. HSingh, B. B.Peter, S.Stur, M. Cells Tissues Organs 1982 114 2 97–105 10.1159/000145583 17728549 so the papillae act like a hairbrush. Some cats, particularly longhaired cats, occasionally regurgitatehairballsof fur that have collected in their stomachs from grooming. These clumps of fur are usually sausage-shaped and aboutconvert2–3cm1onlong. Hairballs can be prevented with remedies that ease elimination of the hair through the gut, as well as regular grooming of the coat with a comb or stiff brush.cite webEwing Tom A Hairy Dilemma: When Hair Balls Aren't Harmless Cat Watch 2006 Feline Health Center, Cornell University http://www.vet.cornell.edu/FHC/news/hair.htm http://webcache.googleusercontent.com/search?q20 June 2013 25 August 2009 Some cats can develop a compulsive behavior known aspsychogenic alopecia, or excessive grooming.cite webFeline Compulsive Behavior Moon-Fanelli Alice Tufts University School of Veterinary Medicine http://www.tufts.edu/vet/vet_common/pdf/petinfo/dvm/case_march2005.pdf 21 December 2011 (Archive)clarifySeptember 2012Missing publication date.
article.heading: Fighting
article.paragraph: Among domestic cats, males are more likely to fight than females.Cite journalLindell Ellen M. Intercat Aggression: A Retrospective Study Examining Types of Aggression, Sexes of Fighting Pairs, and Effectiveness of Treatment Applied Animal Behaviour Science December 1997 55 1–2 153–162 10.1016/S0168-1591(97)00032-4 Among feral cats, the most common reason forCatfight (animal behavior)cat fightingis competition between two males to mate with a female. In such cases, most fights are won by the heavier male.cite journalMating Behaviors, Courtship Rank and Mating Success of Male Feral Cat (''Felis catus'') Akihiro Yamane; Teruo Doi; Yuiti Ono Journal of Ethology 14 1 35–44 1996 10.1007/BF02350090 Another common reason for fighting in domestic cats is the difficulty of establishing territories within a small home.Female cats also fight over territory or to defend their kittens. Neutering will decrease or eliminate this behavior in many cases, suggesting that the behavior is linked tosex hormones.citation neededSeptember 2012

When cats become aggressive, they try to make themselves appear larger and more threatening by raising their fur, arching their backs, turning sideways and hissing or spitting.cite webhttp://animal.discovery.com/guides/cats/behavior/bodylanguageintro.html https://web.archive.org/web/20090224154137/http://animal.discovery.com/guides/cats/behavior/bodylanguageintro.html 24 February 2009 Cat Behavior: Body Language AnimalPlanet.com 2007 7 September 2012Often, the ears are pointed down and back to avoid damage to the inner ear and potentially listen for any changes behind them while focused forward. They may also vocalize loudly and bare their teeth in an effort to further intimidate their opponent. Fights usually consist of grappling and delivering powerful slaps to the face and body with the forepaws as well as bites. Cats also throw themselves to the ground in a defensive posture to rake their opponent's belly with their powerful hind legs.cite webhttps://web.archive.org/web/20041214181209/http://www.hsus.org/pets/pet_care/our_pets_for_life_program/cat_behavior_tip_sheets/aggression_between_family_cats.htmlhttp://www.hsus.org/pets/pet_care/our_pets_for_life_program/cat_behavior_tip_sheets/aggression_between_family_cats.htmlAggression Between Family Cats.14 December 2004The Humane Society of the United States2002

Serious damage is rare, as the fights are usually short in duration, with the loser running away with little more than a few scratches to the face and ears. However, fights for mating rights are typically more severe and injuries may include deep puncture wounds and lacerations. Normally, serious injuries from fighting are limited to infections of scratches and bites, though these can occasionally kill cats if untreated. In addition, bites are probably the main route of transmission offeline immunodeficiency virus.Cite journalFeline Immunodeficiency Virus Infection Pedersen N. C. Yamamoto, J. K.Ishida, T.Hansen, H. Veterinary Immunology and Immunopathology 1989 21 1 111–29 2549690 10.1016/0165-2427(89)90134-7 Sexually active males are usually involved in many fights during their lives, and often have decidedly battered faces with obvious scars and cuts to their ears and noses.
article.heading: Hunting and feeding
article.paragraph: File:Large Siamese cat tosses a mouse.jpgthumbrightA cat that has caught a mouseCats hunt small prey, primarily birds and rodents,and are often used as a form of pest control.Clones, Cats, And Chemicals: Thinking Scientifically About Controversial Issues  Page 9, Irwin L. Slesnick  2004Pests of Crops in Warmer Climates and Their Control  Page 120, Dennis S. Hill  2008Domestic cats are a major predator of wildlife in the United States, killing an estimated 1.43.7 billion birds and 6.920.7 billion mammals annually.cite journalLossScott R.TomWillPeter P.MarraThe impact of free-ranging domestic cats on wildlife of the United StatesNature Communications29 January 20134Article number: 139610.1038/ncomms2380We estimate that free-ranging domestic cats kill 1.4–3.7 billion birds and 6.9–20.7 billion mammals annually.2013NatCo...4E1396Lcite newsThat Cuddly Kitty Is Deadlier Than You Thinkhttp://www.nytimes.com/2013/01/30/science/that-cuddly-kitty-of-yours-is-a-killer.html30 January 2013The New York Times29 January 2013Natalie AngierThe bulk of predation in the United States is done by 80 million feral and stray cats. Effective measures to reduce this population are elusive, meeting opposition from cat enthusiasts.In the case of free-ranging pets, equipping cats with bells and not letting them out at night will reduce wildlife predation.

Free-fed feral cats and house cats tend to consume many small meals in a single day, although the frequency and size of meals varies between individuals.Cite journalBradshaw JW, Goodwin D, Legrand-Defrétin V, Nott HMFood selection by the domestic cat, an obligate carnivoreComp. Biochem. Physiol. A Physiol.1143205–91996875914410.1016/0300-9629(95)02133-7Cats use two hunting strategies, either stalking prey actively, or waiting in ambush until an animal comes close enough to be captured. Although it is not certain, the strategy used may depend on the prey species in the area, with cats waiting in ambush outside burrows, but tending to actively stalk birds.Cite bookTurnerDennis C.BatesonPatrick (eds.)The Domestic Cat: The Biology of its Behaviour20002ndCambridge University PressCambridge, England0-521-63648-5rp153

Most breeds of cat have a noted fondness for settling in high places, or perching. In the wild, a higher place may serve as a concealed site from which to hunt; domestic cats may strike prey by pouncing from a perch such as a tree branch, as does aleopard.cite webWhy Do Cats Like High Places? Nash Holly http://www.peteducation.com/article.cfm?chttps://web.archive.org/web/20080102145008/http://www.peteducation.com/article.cfm?cls2 January 2008 PetEducation.com Drs. Foster & Smith Inc. clarifySeptember 2012Missing publication date.Another possible explanation is that height gives the cat a better observation point, allowing it to survey its territory. During a fall from a high place, a cat can reflexively twist its body and right itself using its acuteequilibrioceptionsense of balanceand flexibility.cite webFalling Cats http://www.verrueckte-experimente.de/leseproben_e.html https://web.archive.org/web/20051026122408/http://www.verrueckte-experimente.de/leseproben_e.html 26 October 200524 October 2005 ClarifySeptember 2012This is not a proper reference citation. Use Cite web or similar to provide source details.This is known as thecat righting reflex. An individual cat always rights itself in the same way, provided it has the time to do so, during a fall. The height required for this to occur is around 90 cm (3 ft). Cats without a tail (e.g.Manx (cat)Manx cats) also have this ability, since a cat mostly moves its hind legs and relies on conservation ofangular momentumto set up for landing, and the tail is little used for this feat.cite webhttp://helix.gatech.edu/Classes/ME3760/1998Q3/Projects/Nguyen/ How Does a Cat Always Land on Its Feet? Nguyen Huy D. Dynamics II (ME 3760) Course Materials 1998 Georgia Institute of Technology, School of Medical Engineering 15 May 2007tertiaryDecember 2011

The perhaps best known element of cats' hunting behavior, which is commonly misunderstood and often appalls cat owners because it looks like torture, is that cats often appear to "play" with prey by releasing it after capture. This behavior is due to an instinctive imperative to ensure that the prey is weak enough to be killed without endangering the cat.cite webWhy do cats play with their food?http://azdailysun.com/lifestyles/pets/article_46a97775-232d-5e56-b0ea-dd1c8782b062.htmlArizona Daily Sun15 August 2011This behavior is referred to in theidiom"cat-and-mouse game" or simply "cat and mouse".

Another poorly understood element of cat hunting behavior is the presentation of prey to human guardians.EthologyEthologistPaul Leyhausen proposed that cats adopt humans into their social group and share excess kill with others in the group according to thedominance hierarchy, in which humans are reacted to as if they are at, or near, the top.Cite bookCat Behavior: The Predatory and Social Behavior of Domestic and Wild Cats Leyhausen Paul 1978 Garland STPM Pr New York 978-0-8240-7017-5 Anthropologist and zoologistDesmond Morris, in his 1986 bookCatwatching, suggests, when cats bring home mice or birds, they are attempting to teach their human to hunt, or trying to help their human as if feeding "an elderly cat, or an inept kitten".Cite bookCatwatching: Why Cats Purr and Everything Else You Ever Wanted to Know Desmond Morris 1986 Crown Publishing clarifySeptember 2012Missing page numbercite webhttp://www.livescience.com/34471-cats-dead-animals.htmlWhy Do Cats Bring Home Dead Animals - Cats Dead MiceLiveScience.com2 September 2015Morris's theory is inconsistent with the fact that male cats also bring home prey, despite males having no involvement with raising kittens.rp153

Domestic cats select food based on its temperature, smell and texture, disliking chilled foods and responding most strongly to moist foods rich in amino acids, which are similar to meat.Cats may reject novel flavors (a response termedneophobia) and learn quickly totaste aversionavoid foods that have tasted unpleasantin the past.They may also avoid sugary foods and milk. Most adult cats arelactose intolerant; the sugars in milk are not easily digested and may cause soft stools ordiarrhea.Cite journalBlood Sugar Levels and Renal Sugar Excretion after the Intake of High Carbohydrate Diets in Cats Kienzle E. Journal of Nutrition 1994 124 12 Supplement 2563S–2567S 7996238 http://jn.nutrition.org/content/124/12_Suppl/2563S.full.pdf
They can also develop odd eating habits. Some cats like to eat or chew on other things, most commonly wool, but also plastic, cables, paper, string, aluminum foil/Christmas tree tinsel, or even coal. This condition,pica (disorder)pica, can threaten their health, depending on the amount and toxicity of the items eaten.Cite journalFactors affecting pica in the domestic cat Bradshaw John W. S. Applied Animal Behaviour Science April 1997 52 3–4 373–379 10.1016/S0168-1591(96)01136-7 cite webhttp://www.vmth.ucdavis.edu/home/beh/feline_behavior/pica.html Pica: The Un-finicky Feline – Chewing or Eating Cords, Fabric, Houseplants, Etc. University of California School of Veterinary Medicine 6 September 2009 tertiaryDecember 2011

Though cats usually prey on animals less than half their size, a feral cat in Australia had been photographed to kill an adultpademelonweighing around the cat's size at 4 kg (8.8 lb).cite webhttp://www.abc.net.au/news/2015-03-30/scientists-catch-a-feral-cat-killing-a-large-mammal-on-camera-f/6357868Scientists catch a feral cat killing a large mammal on camera 'for the first time'ABC News2 September 2015

Since cats cannot fully close their lips around something to create suction, they use a lapping method with the tongue to draw liquid upwards into their mouths. Lapping at a rate of four times a second, the cat touches the smooth tip of its tongue to the surface of the water, and quickly retracts it, drawing water upwards.Cite newsWade Nicholas For Cats, a Big Gulp With a Touch of the Tongue New York Times 11 November 2010 http://www.nytimes.com/2010/11/12/science/12cats.html 12 November 2010
article.heading: Play
article.paragraph: MainCat play and toysFile:Play fight between cats.webmhd.webmthumbnailthumbtime=4alt=Play fight between kittens, age 14 weeksPlay fight between kittens, age 14 weeksDomestic cats, especially young kittens, are known for their love of play. This behavior mimics hunting and is important in helping kittens learn topredationstalk, capture, and killprey.Cite journalPoirier F. E. Hussey L. K. Nonhuman Primate Learning: The Importance of Learning from an Evolutionary Perspective Anthropology and Education Quarterly 13 2 133–148 1 July 1982 10.1525/aeq.1982.13.2.05x1830j 3216627 Cats also engage in play fighting, with each other and with humans. This behavior may be a way for cats to practice the skills needed for real combat, and might also reduce any fear they associate with launching attacks on other animals.Cite bookAnimal Play: Evolutionary, Comparative, and Ecological Perspectives Byers John A. Bekoff Marc [[Cambridge University Press]] Cambridge, England 1998 135 0-521-58656-9

Owing to the close similarity between play and hunting, cats prefer to play with objects that resemble prey, such as small furry toys that move rapidly, but rapidly lose interest (they becomehabituationhabituated) in a toy they have played with before.Cite journalObject Play in Adult Domestic Cats: The Roles of Habituation and Disinhibition Hall Sarah L. Applied Animal Behaviour Science 2002 79 3 263–271 10.1016/S0168-1591(02)00153-3 Cats also tend to play with toys more when they are hungry.Cite journalHall Sarah L. The Influence of Hunger on Object Play by Adult Domestic Cats Applied Animal Behaviour Science June 1998 58 1–2 143–150 10.1016/S0168-1591(97)00136-6 String is often used as a toy, but if it is eaten, it can become caught at the base of the cat's tongue and then move into theintestines, a medical emergency which can cause serious illness, even death.Cite journalMacPhail Catriona Gastrointestinal obstruction Clinical Techniques in Small Animal Practice November 2002 17 4 178–183 10.1053/svms.2002.36606 12587284 Owing to the risks posed by cats eating string, it is sometimes replaced with alaser pointer's dot, which cats may chase.Cite newshttp://www.poconorecord.com/apps/pbcs.dll/article?AIDFat Indoor Cats Need Exercise 10 December 2006 [[Pocono Record]] tertiarySeptember 2012While concerns have been raised about the safety of playing with lasers, John Marshall, anophthalmologistatSt Thomas' Hospital, has stated it would be "virtually impossible" to blind a cat with a laser pointer."Eye Expert Challenges Laser Pen 'Danger'"BBC News, 24 November 1997
article.heading: Reproduction

link.part: When cats mate, the tomcat (male) bites the scruff of the female's neck as she assumes a position conducive tomatingknown aslordosis behavior.

article.paragraph: Female cats are seasonallypolyestrous, which means they may have many periods ofEstrusheatover the course of a year, the season beginning in spring and ending in late autumn. Heat periods occur about every two weeks and last about 4 to 7 days.Multiple males will be attracted to a female in heat. The males will fight over her, and the victor wins the right to mate. At first, the female rejects the male, but eventually the female allows the male to mate. The female utters a loud yowl as the male pulls out of her because a malecat's penishas a band of about 120150 backwards-pointingpenile spines, which are about 1 mm long;Cite journalPenile Spines of the Domestic Cat: Their Endocrine-behavior Relations Aronson L. R. Cooper M. L. Anat. Rec. 1967 157 1 71–78 6030760 10.1002/ar.1091570111 http://www.catcollection.org/files/PenileSpines.pdf upon withdrawal of the penis, the spines rake the walls of the female'svagina, which is a trigger forovulation. This act also occurs to clear the vagina of other sperm in the context of a second (or more) mating, thus giving the later males a larger chance of conception.Citation neededOctober 2011

After mating, the female washes hervulvathoroughly. If a male attempts to mate with her at this point, the female will attack him. After about 20 to 30 minutes, once the female is finished grooming, the cycle will repeat.

Because ovulation is not always triggered by a single mating, females may not be impregnated by the first male with which they mate.Cite journalWildt D. E. Seager S. W. Chakraborty P. K. Effect of Copulatory Stimuli on Incidence of Ovulation and on Serum Luteinizing Hormone in the Cat Endocrinology 1980 107 4 1212–7 7190893 10.1210/endo-107-4-1212 Furthermore, cats aresuperfecundationsuperfecund; that is, a female may mate with more than one male when she is in heat, with the result that different kittens in a litter may have different fathers.cite webhttp://vlsstore.com/Media/PublicationsArticle/PV_23_12_1049.pdf Prolific Cats: The Estrous Cycle Veterinary Learning Systems 19 June 2009 dead linkJanuary 2013

At 124 hours after conception, the morula forms. At 148 hours, early blastocysts form. At 1012 days, implantation occurs.cite webhttp://www.biolreprod.org/content/51/3/452.full.pdfBiology of ReproductionIn Vivo Embryogenesis, Embryo Migration and Embryonic Mortality in the Domestic CatWilliam F Swanson, Terri L Roth, David E. Wiltcite webhttp://php.med.unsw.edu.au/embryology/index.php?titleCat Development – EmbryologyPhp.med.unsw.edu.au6 June 201322 September 2013

Thegestationperiod for cats is between 64 and 67 days, with an average of 66 days.Cite journalTsutsui T. Stabenfeldt G. H. Biology of Ovarian Cycles, Pregnancy and pseudopregnancy in the Domestic Cat J. Reprod. Fertil. Suppl. 47 29–35 1993 8229938 The size of aLitter (animal)litterusually is three to five kittens, with the first litter usually smaller than subsequent litters. Kittens are weaned between six and seven weeks old, and cats normally reach sexual maturity at 510 months (females) and to 57 months (males), although this can vary depending on breed.Females can have two to three litters per year, so may produce up to 150 kittens in their breeding span of around ten years.

Cats are ready to go to new homes at about 12 weeks of age,Cite bookThe Complete Book of Cat Care: How to Raise a Happy and Healthy CatBehrendKatrinWeglerMonikatranslated from German by Elizabeth D. Crawford1991Barron's Educational Series, Inc.Hauppauge, NY0-8120-4613-728when they are ready to leave their mother. They can be surgicallyneuteringsterilized(spayed orcastrationcastrated) as early as 7 weeks to limit unwanted reproduction.Cite journalEarly-age Neutering of Dogs and Cats in the United States (A Review) Olson P. N. Kustritz M. V. Johnston S. D. J. Reprod. Fertil. Suppl. 2001 57 223–232 11787153 This surgery also prevents undesirable sex-related behavior, such as aggression,spraying (animal behavior)territory marking(spraying urine) in males and yowling (calling) in females. Traditionally, this surgery was performed at around six to nine months of age, but it is increasingly being performed prior topuberty, at about three to six months.cite journalDetermining the optimal age for gonadectomy of dogs and cats Root Kustritz Margaret V. Journal of American Veterinary Medicine 2007 231 11 1665–1675 http://www.imom.org/spay-neuter/pdf/kustritz.pdf 10.2460/javma.231.11.1665 18052800 In the US, about 80% of household cats are neutered.Cite journalPopulation characteristics and neuter status of cats living in households in the United States Chu Karyen Anderson W. M. Rieser M. Y. Journal of the American Veterinary Medical Association 2009 234 8 1023–1030 10.2460/javma.234.8.1023 19366332

Habitats
article.paragraph: File:Black cat being snowed on.jpgthumbrightAblack catin snowy weather.Cats are acosmopolitan speciesand are found across much of the world.Geneticist Stephen James O'Brien, of theNational Cancer InstituteinFrederick, Maryland, remarked on how successful cats have been in evolutionary terms: "Cats are one of evolution's most charismatic creatures. They can live on the highest mountains and in the hottest deserts."cite newsRandersonJamesFrom Lion to Moggie: How Cats Climbed their Family Tree[[The Guardian]]London6 January 2006They are extremely adaptable and are now present on all continents exceptAntarctica, and on 118 of the 131 main groups of islandseven on sub-Antarctic islands such as theKerguelen Islands.Cite journalSpatio-temporal variation in cat population density in a sub-Antarctic environment Say Ludovic Polar Biology 2002 25 2 90–95 10.1007/s003000100316 Cite journalBiological Invasions in the Antarctic: Extent, Impacts and Implications Frenot Y. Chown, Steven L.Whinam, JennieSelkirk, Patricia M.Convey, PeterSkotnicki, MaryBergstrom, Dana M. Biological Reviews 2005 80 1 45–72 10.1017/S1464793104006542

Feral cats can live in forests, grasslands, tundra, coastal areas, agricultural land, scrublands, urban areas, and wetlands.cite webhttp://www.issg.org/database/species/ecology.asp?siGlobal Invasive Species Database Ecology of ''Felis catus'' Invasive Species Specialist Group 2006 31 August 2009 Their habitats even include small oceanic islands with no human inhabitants.Further, the close relatives of domestic cats, theAfrican wildcat(Felis silvestris lybica) and the Arabiansand cat(Felis margarita) both inhabit desert environments,and domestic cats still show similar adaptations and behaviors.The cat's ability to thrive in almost any terrestrial habitat has led to its designation as one of the world's worstinvasive species.cite webhttp://www.issg.org/booklet.pdf https://web.archive.org/web/20070927223530/http://www.issg.org/booklet.pdf 27 September 2007 100 of the World's Worst Invasive Alien Species: A Selection from the Global Invasive Species Database The Invasive Species Specialist Group 2000 31 August 2009

As domestic cats are little altered from wildcats, they can readily interbreed. Thishybrid (biology)hybridizationposes a danger to the genetic distinctiveness of some wildcat populations, particularly inScotlandandHungaryand possibly also theIberian Peninsula.Cite journalOliveiraR.Godinho, R.Randi, E.Alves, P. article.heading: Feral cats
article.paragraph: Feral cats are domestic cats that were born in or have reverted to a wild state. They are unfamiliar with and wary of humans and roam freely in urban and rural areas.The numbers of feral cats is not known, but estimates of the US feral population range from 25 to 60 million.Feral cats may live alone, but most are found in largeferal cat colonycolonies, which occupy a specific territory and are usually associated with a source of food.cite webhttp://www.hsus.org/pets/issues_affecting_our_pets/feral_cats/feral_cats_frequently_asked_questions.html#1_What_is_a_feral_cathttps://web.archive.org/web/20080501093143/http://www.hsus.org/pets/issues_affecting_our_pets/feral_cats/feral_cats_frequently_asked_questions.html#1_What_is_a_feral_cat1 May 2008What is the difference between a stray cat and a feral cat?Humane Society of the United StatesFamous feral cat colonies are found in Rome around theColosseumandForum Romanum, with cats at some of these sites being fed and given medical attention by volunteers.cite webhttp://www.romancats.com/index_eng.phpTorre Argentina cat shelter.17 June 2009

Public attitudes towards feral cats vary widely, ranging from seeing them as free-ranging pets, to regarding them as vermin.Cite bookHumane Society Press 0-9658942-7-4 Rowan Andrew N. Deborah J. Salem The State of the Animals II: 2003 November 2003 4 http://www.hsus.org/web-files/PDF/hsp/SOA_3-2005_Chap4.pdf https://web.archive.org/web/20061110230426/http://www.hsus.org/web-files/PDF/hsp/SOA_3-2005_Chap4.pdf 10 November 2006 One common approach to reducing the feral cat population is termed 'trap-neuter-return', where the cats are trapped,neuteringneutered,immunizationimmunizedagainst rabies and thefeline leukemia virus, and then released. Before releasing them back into their feral colonies, the attending veterinarian often nips the tip off one ear to mark it as neutered and inoculated, since these cats may be trapped again. Volunteers continue to feed and give care to these cats throughout their lives. Given this support, their lifespans are increased, and behavior and nuisance problems caused by competition for food are reduced.

Even in places with ancient and numerous cat populations, such asWestern Europe, cats appear to be growing in number and independently of their environments'carrying capacity(such as the numbers of prey available).Cite journalFood Habits and Prey Impact by Feral and House-based Domestic Cats in a Rural Area in Southern Sweden Liberg O. article.paragraph: mainHuman interaction with catsCats are commonpetsin Europe and North America, and their worldwide population exceeds 500 million.Although cat guardianship has commonly been associated with women,Cite newshttp://www.nytimes.com/2008/10/05/fashion/05cats.htmlMore Men Are Unabashedly Embracing Their Love of CatsNew York TimesAbby Ellin30 August 20095 October 2008a 2007Gallup pollreported that men and women were equally likely to own a cat.cite webhttp://www.gallup.com/poll/102952/companionship-love-animals-drive-pet-ownership.aspxCompanionship and Love of Animals Drive Pet OwnershipGallup, IncJeffrey M.Jones30 November 200730 August 2009
